publicwhip.spmotion: *S3M-6971 John Park: Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the CREATE Campaign for careers in Scotland, an initiative of the Institute of Career Guidance, and notes that the campaign aims to engage decision makers and employers in maximising Scottish talent by focusing on the CREATE Campaign principles, which are careers services that maximise individuals’ talents and skills, realising everyone’s potential through universal, targeted and high quality careers provision with consistent standards across the United Kingdom, entitlement to impartial careers information, advice and guidance, access to diverse well-trained and qualified careers professionals at all times and places most relevant to individuals’ needs, tangible results demonstrating that professional careers work contributes to employment, social mobility, diversity and equality and excellence in careers services, equipping individuals with confidence, resilience and motivation to succeed in a fast-changing global economy. Supported by: Jackie Baillie*, Margaret Curran*, David Whitton*, Rhona Brankin*, Mary Mulligan*, Trish Godman*, Bill Kidd*
S3M-6971 Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland (lodged on 13 September 2010) Elaine Smith*, Hugh O’Donnell*
S3M-6971 Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland (lodged on 13 September 2010) Jamie Hepburn*, George Foulkes*, Sarah Boyack*, Hugh Henry*, Elaine Murray*

S3M-6971 John Park: Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the CREATE Campaign for careers in Scotland, an initiative of the Institute of Career Guidance, and notes that the campaign aims to engage decision makers and employers in maximising Scottish talent by focusing on the CREATE Campaign principles, which are careers services that maximise individuals’ talents and skills, realising everyone’s potential through universal, targeted and high quality careers provision with consistent standards across the United Kingdom, entitlement to impartial careers information, advice and guidance, access to diverse well-trained and qualified careers professionals at all times and places most relevant to individuals’ needs, tangible results demonstrating that professional careers work contributes to employment, social mobility, diversity and equality and excellence in careers services, equipping individuals with confidence, resilience and motivation to succeed in a fast-changing global economy. Supported by: Jackie Baillie, Margaret Curran, David Whitton, Rhona Brankin, Mary Mulligan, Trish Godman, Bill Kidd, Elaine Smith, Hugh O’Donnell, Jamie Hepburn, George Foulkes, Sarah Boyack, Hugh Henry, Elaine Murray, Ken Macintosh*
S3M-6971 Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland (lodged on 13 September 2010) James Kelly*
S3M-6971 Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland (lodged on 13 September 2010) Johann Lamont*
S3M-6971 Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland (lodged on 13 September 2010) Mr Frank McAveety*
S3M-6971 Welcoming the CREATE Campaign for Careers in Scotland (lodged on 13 September 2010) Cathy Jamieson*
